Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Developing Alternate Aquafeeds Utilizing Marine Invertebrates and Plants Cultured from Fish Fecal and Feed Waste
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase I project seeks to develop an alternate aquafeed that does not rely on the inclusion of captured, oceanic forage fish such as menhaden and sardines for its omega-3 content and is suitable for culturing marine fish in land-based recirculating aquaculture systems (RASs). Specifically, six alternate fish feeds will be formulated, pelletized and fed to California yellowtail (Seriola lalandi) in 18 saltwater, indoor tanks, containing 80 fish per tank in a size range starting at 20 grams up to 450 grams. A conventional, commercially available fish feed will be used as a control. Suitability will be measured by how well the growth and survival rates of the test group compare to the control group. The alternate feeds will utilize various substitutes for the absent fish meal, including microalgae, invertebrates such as sandworms and insect-derived meal. The ideal alternate feed will be price competitive, generally available and sourced from local processing wastes or cultured in the fecal and fed waste naturally generated from fish production in an aquafarm. The latter is feasible within RASs since the flow of nutrients can be directed beneficially from one crop to another in a web of interactive species.


The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to demonstrate that alternate aquafeeds are technically feasible. They can be price-competitive with conventional feeds. Companies selling conventional fish feed containing a substantial component of captured fish now advise customers to anticipate annual price raises as the growth of aquaculture combined with excessive fishing pressure impacts demand and supply respectively. Certainly the rise can be accommodated in the short term, but it behooves aquafarmers to develop alternatives since they can only raise prices to a point after which they become uncompetitive with fisheries catch while seafood customers turn to other protein. On the positive side, there is a growing concern by seafood distributors, chefs and consumers whether seafood is or is not ?sustainable?, that is whether it abuses or contributes to a healthy global ecosystem. Thus, a clear commercial opportunity is emerging, perhaps as a niche market at the outset, but almost certainly a very large market in time as aquaculture continues to grow.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Acadia Harvest Inc.’s (AHI) business is closed-containment aquaculture. With National Science Foundation (NSF) support, AHI has developed innovative approaches to zero waste fish culture by utilizing fish wastes as resources. Fish feces and feed residuals are utilized to culture by-products. The method is called integrated multi-trophic aquaculture (IMTA). Building on this technology with the NSF Phase I and IB award, the company initiated the development of fish feeds that substitute for fish meal and fish oil (FM&O) derived from wild-caught forage fish. The combination of these technologies, waste management and alternate aquafeed, will boost AHI’s branding efforts in selling sustainable seafood products to a ready market.

The STTR Phase I aquafeed feasibility effort substituted various nutrients and agricultural materials for FM&O in aquafeeds that were formulated and pelletized by Dr. Rick Barrow, the Senior Fish Physiologist in USDA’s Aquaculture Research Service, Bozeman, Montana. For Phase IB, marine residuals from seafood processing lines were substituted. All the formulations were run through feed trials with AHI’s California yellowtail and black sea bass in its experimental facilities at the University of Maine Center for Cooperative Aquaculture Research, Franklin, Maine. The experimental feeds were found to promote superior growth compared to standard commercial fish feed.

Forage fish are small pelagic fish near the base of the oceanic food chain. They include sardines, menhaden, herring, and similar species that swim in large schools feeding on planktonic organisms. They are in turn preyed upon by larger fish, sea birds and marine mammals. Each year approximately 500,000 tons of forage fish are caught worldwide and converted into FM&O and fertilizer. Some populations such the California sardine are so depleted that baby seals are now reported as starving to death in large numbers, and stocks of predator fish higher up the ocean food chain are also dropping in numbers. Moreover, as global aquaculture increases in volume, so does the demand for FM&O, threatening other pelagic populations and raising the price of aquafeed. AHI and others are investigating ways to develop alternate aquafeeds believing that bona fide substitutes will share the $10 billion market and relieve fishing pressure on our oceans. This is both a business opportunity and an environmentally responsible goal.


Last Modified: 10/05/2015
Modified by: Taylor A Pryor
